Yes, there are many notable examples of modern architecture in nearby areas that have respected the traditional style of their surroundings. For example:

1. The Tate Modern in London: The Tate Modern is a modern art gallery located in a former power station on the south bank of the Thames, just across the river from the historic St. Paul's Cathedral. The building's conversion was undertaken by architects Herzog & de Meuron, who incorporated elements of the original power station's industrial architecture into the new design.

2. The Design Museum in Kensington: The Design Museum is located in the former Commonwealth Institute building in Kensington, west London. The building is an example of 20th-century modern architecture and has been repurposed for the museum by John Pawson, who respected the original design features while incorporating new elements, including an iconic atrium.

3. The Oxo Tower on the South Bank: The Oxo Tower is a landmark building on the south bank of the Thames in central London. The building has been repurposed as a mixed-use development, incorporating a restaurant, boutique shops, and galleries. The contemporary design features transparent glazing and steel, while the original details such as the Art Deco relief can be seen in the façade.

These examples show that modern architecture can complement and enhance the traditional style of an area by respecting the existing architectural heritage and culture.
